column3: 599^B00116TCX8^http://books.google.com/books/content?id=lbOOJGLxM9MC&printsec=frontcover&img=1&zoom=1&source=gbs_api^Authors^The final POIROT omnibus
column4: featuring the last four appearances of the detective's side-kick
column5: the sleuthing crime novelist Ariadne Oliver: Third Girl
column6: Hallowe'en Party
column7: Elephants Can Remember and The Pale Horse. Poirot and Mrs Oliver continue their sleuthing in the 1960s in four uncharacteristically 'modern' novels with an added twist of danger...Third Girl Poirot finally admits he is growing old as a perplexed girl thinks she may have killed someone. Here Christie dragged Poirot into the swinging 60s and effectively squared him up against a world featuring sex
column8: drugs and hippies. Hallowe'en Party A teenage murder witness is drowned in a tub of apples. This was only the second time Christie wrote about the death of a child
column9: and is all the more engrossing for it. Elephants Can Remember An old husband and wife double murder has never been solved -- until now. This was the very last Poirot story that Agatha Christie wrote
column10: and garnered good reviews. The Pale Horse A priest's death leads to sinister goings-on in an old country inn. This bonus novel featured Mrs Oliver for once without Poirot and was one of Christie's darkest stories

column4: banned in Britain for almost thirty years
column5: now reinvigorated in a new Harper Perennial Modern Classics edition. A penniless and as yet unpublished writer
column6: Henry Miller arrived in Paris in 1930. Leaving behind a disintegrating marriage and an unhappy career in America
column7: he threw himself into the low-life of bohemian Paris with unwavering gusto. A fictional account of Miller's adventures amongst the prostitutes and pimps
column8: the penniless painters and writers of Montparnasse
column9: Tropic of Cancer is an extravagant and rhapsodic hymn to a world of unrivalled eroticism and freedom. Tropic of Cancer's 1934 publication in France was hailed by Samuel Beckett as 'a momentous event in the history of modern writing'. The novel was subsequently banned in the UK and the USA and not released for publication for a further thirty years.
